abs: Kriging models have been widely used as surrogate models to reduce computational costs in structural reliability analysis with time-consuming numerical models (e.g. finite element analysis (FEA) structural models). Their interpolation capability and prediction uncertainty measure have been explored in the de-velopment of efficient adaptive surrogate models with active refinement algorithms. The latter use the predic-tion uncertainty measure to identify new samples that should be sequentially added to the design of experiments, allowing an effective control of the surrogate model accuracy. The refinement process proceeds until prescribed convergence or stopping criteria are satisfied. In the present paper an additional stopping cri-terion for active refinement algorithms in Kriging surrogate models is proposed. It exploits the possible stabi-lization of the failure probability prediction during the active refinement process, indicating that the additional samples are not contributing to improve significantly the prediction accuracy. The refinement process can therefore be stopped to maximize the efficiency. The performance of the proposed additional stopping criteri-on in terms of efficiency and accuracy is demonstrated in the paper with a numerical example involving an advanced nonlinear FEA structural model and its practical usefulness and limitations are discussed.
title: A study on a stopping criterion for active refinement algorithms in Kriging surrogate models
